Text.Value: Mystic Carrion was the one behind this. It wasn't Oskar's fault.
Why does everything always have to revolve around Oskar Fevras?
The Kerri Oskar spoke of was kind and gentle. This isn't the real you.
Why should I trust you? Why would I ever trust him?
Attack.
And who are you, some fawning obsessive like that rich cow 'Lady Jannath'? I bet Oskar loves that.
If you believe that, then why are you helping him?
He won't disturb you again. I'll make sure of it.
And you think he'll listen to you? He doesn't listen to anyone.
I'm here because Oskar wanted me here. To make him feel better.
What are you saying? You're trying to confuse me.
My decision had nothing to do with him. I did this because I was so fucking sad. All the time.
And he deserves it.
Touch him, and you'll face all of nature's fury. You'll face me.
Listen - you're lost and in pain. This plane is not meant for spirits.
You're a worthless human and a worse artist, Oskar Fevras. You never should have brought me here.
Leave Oskar to his fate.
This man is under my protection - I cannot let you hurt him.
Do something - she's going to kill him!
Tell Oskar what he wants to hear. OUT WITH IT.
Attack.
Then you're as bad as him.
Please... Kerri, my darling, listen to me -

EditorData.NodeContext: Frightened, hoping his charm will calm her down

Text.Value: Die with him if you love him so much.
I don't take orders from most people - especially not a ghost. Stand down.
NO! Enough of your whining. ENOUGH.

EditorData.NodeContext: Furious, taking control of the situation

Text.Value: Why should I be the better person? He's the one tormenting me!
You're on the Material Plane - my hunting ground. Back off, or face me.
Neither would you, if you'd been dragged here by this self-important arsehole.
Selfish, arrogant bastard of an artist. I wanted to be left in peace.

EditorData.AnimationTags: oskar cowering can use HUM_M_Rig_DFLT_CINE_ArmCoverFace_StandL_01 construct anim
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Oskar cowers as Kerri turns to her right 80 degrees towards him. The player edges closer.
EditorData.NodeContext: Fury starting to break, a hint of sadness beneath it all

Text.Value: You will burn like everything else on this plane, spirit, if you harm this man.
Ask yourself  - will killing this man make you happy? Give you purpose? Or are you better than this?
Fine. If Oskar wants the truth, he can have it: we were a fling, nothing more.
Your spirit is twisted by hate and fear, but this isn't you. You're kind and gentle - I can sense it.
You had a message for us, remember? You were going to tell us why you died by your own hand.
No more harm will come to you by sharing your story. But it could help Oskar.
You owe Oskar nothing. He only brought you here to soothe his conscience.
I only wished to explain myself. To make you see how -

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Raises a hand, as though uncertain about drawing attention to himself
EditorData.NodeContext: trying to say "how sorry I was", but gets cut off

Text.Value: Calm yourself, shade. We can resolve this peacefully.
Quiet, Oskar. That isn't helping.

EditorData.NodeContext: Low, strict - trying not to attrack Kerri's attention

Text.Value: Who are you? Get out. GET OUT!

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Kerri has cornered a very frightened-looking Oskar. Oskar holds up his hands in a placatory/calming gesture. Kerri turns to her left 80 degrees and sees the player, face twisted with fury.

Text.Value: DO NOT INTERFERE. He's coming home with me.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Kerri turns to her left 90 degrees from Oskar, and squares up to the player on DO NOT INTERFERE. She blocks their access to Oskar.

Text.Value: Please. Tell us what happened to you.
*The spirit's aura flickers, changes. She is confused, lost - dragged here unwillingly by a man who refused to let her leave.*
To the realms of the dead? You'll kill him!
It's so hard to think. I don't remember.
Save your tears for the Ethereal Plane...

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Kerri takes a big step towards Oskar, who shields his face, expecting an attack.

Text.Value: Do not be shackled by your story, spirit. Share it - let it set you free.
And how does that help me? Or is it just to help him?
And let Oskar walk away? No, I won't do it.
You owe Oskar an explanation. And you're going to give it to him...
Kerri, my sweet meat. I just need to know that what you did... that it wasn't my fault -
I'm sorry, Kerri. I had no idea. But I - I was truly not to blame?
Oskar does not matter - you do. Say what you need to say to him - no matter how difficult it is.
Oskar finds it easier to imagine a world where women kill themselves over him than one where they have their own bloody problems.
No, you weren't, so you and your poxy paintings stay away from me. We're done, Oskar. Over. Now let me rest in bloody peace.

EditorData.NodeContext: Pissed off but back in control of herself. A stern warning at the end.

Text.Value: You brought me here. YOU DID THIS.
Another who wants to control me.
You came to deliver a message. To tell us what led to your fate.
I won't let your soul be bound unjustly, spirit. Tell us of your fate, and you will be freed.
Calm, spirit. Tell us of your fate, then your soul shall be freed - I swear it.
I don't care if you're a spirit. Touch him, and I'll break you.
Oh, my sweet Kerri. What did I do to you?
You don't seem all that peaceful to me.
I don't owe anyone anything.
I'll burn you, and potentially everyone else here, to ash if you don't stop this.
Hurt this man, and you will face the consequences, spirit.
I rather like interfering. It's kind of my thing.
Stop this, or I will educate you on the true meaning of torment and suffering.
He called me here. Trapped me. Pathetic little childish boy.
Your bonds are broken. Go, if that is your wish.
But you're right.
Why am I here? I shouldn't be here, I shouldn't be.

EditorData.NodeContext: Angry, distressed. Unclear whether she's about to lash out, or break down in tears. Almost accusing the player.

Synopsis: Dialog with the ghost of Kerri Evenfield, now freed from Oskar's body and hells-bent on taking him to the afterlife with her. She's incandescent with angry, but if the player successfully calms her anger, they can hear her explanation of her recent suicide, and get her to leave peacefully. Otherwise, they end up in combat.
